content: I'm considering having an MS student formalize the basic theory of Hilbert C∗C^*C∗-modules, with the idea being that it would eventually be included in mathlib. I think I would probably know about it if so, but I wanted to make sure no one else is currently working on it, and assuming not, discourage anyone from doing so for now. In addition, if anyone thinks this is a crazy idea, please say I'm crazy.

My experience with getting students to formalise something is that you can almost always get some code out of them but it's quite another thing getting it to be mathlib standard. For example I've had two students do projects in group cohomology (one for low degree, one for general degree) but it's still not in mathlib
The student gets the code running and then graduates and moves onto other things. Course, if you then want to take over and do the PR work yourself, this works
Do you plan to do it by generalizing inner_product_space?
Yes, I imagine I'll have to do some of the PRs.

Yes, the goal will be to generalize inner_product_space eventually and have this as a replacement. Of course, as Kevin points out, my primary goal will be graduation, with getting this into mathlib as secondary, so if we have to cut a few corners initially then so be it. In that case, it would take me some extra work to get it to be a drop-in replacement.
Sounds good! Maybe doing it the other way around would be an option as well: generalize inner_product_space first, and then have the student build on that.
What do you mean exactly? How would I generalize inner_product_space without just developing C∗C^*C∗-modules myself?
I haven't look in enough detail to know if it's possible or really makes sense, but you could imagine just generalizing the definition of inner_product_space without touching the API.
I'll look into it and think about it, thanks.
